I'll help you create a comprehensive implementation plan for the reliability score calculation feature. Let me start with the deep codebase investigation.

## Phase 0: Deep Codebase Investigation

Let me first read the spec and explore the codebase structure.

entries.detail:
1→# Reliability Score Calculation
     2→
     3→Automated reliability scoring system that calculates worker scores (1-5 stars) based on attendance rate, punctuality rate, and average ratings from businesses. Uses weighted formula: 40% attendance, 30% punctuality, 30% ratings. Updates automatically after each completed job.
     4→
     5→## Rationale
     6→Reliability scores are the platform's key differentiator, addressing the no-show and inconsistent quality pain points. Scores provide businesses with confidence in worker dependability and incentivize workers to maintain high standards.
     7→
     8→## User Stories
     9→- As a business, I want to see worker reliability scores so that I can hire dependable workers
    10→- As a worker, I want to earn a high score so that I can get more job opportunities
    11→- As a worker, I want to understand my score calculation so that I can improve
    12→
    13→## Acceptance Criteria
    14→- [ ] Reliability scores are calculated automatically after each job
    15→- [ ] Score formula: 40% attendance + 30% punctuality + 30% ratings
    16→- [ ] Scores range from 1.0 to 5.0 stars
    17→- [ ] Scores update in real-time
    18→- [ ] Score calculation is transparent and auditable
    19→- [ ] Workers need 5+ completed jobs to have a reliable score
    20→- [ ] Score history is tracked for trend analysis
    21→

1→// ============================================================================
     2→// Reliability Score Edge Function
     3→// ============================================================================
     4→// Calculates and updates worker reliability scores based on:
     5→// - Booking completion rate (attendance)
     6→// - Average rating from reviews
     7→// - Recent activity (last 90 days)
     8→//
     9→// POST /functions/v1/reliability-score
    10→// Body: { worker_id: string }
    11→// ============================================================================
    12→
    13→import { serve } from 'https://deno.land/std@0.168.0/http/server.ts'
    14→import { createClient } from 'https://esm.sh/@supabase/supabase-js@2.38.4'
    15→
    16→// CORS headers for browser requests
    17→const corsHeaders = {
    18→  'Access-Control-Allow-Origin': '*',
    19→  'Access-Control-Allow-Headers': 'authorization, x-client-info, apikey, content-type',
    20→}
    21→
    22→serve(async (req) => {
    23→  // Handle CORS preflight
    24→  if (req.method === 'OPTIONS') {
    25→    return new Response('ok', { headers: corsHeaders })
    26→  }
    27→
    28→  try {
    29→    // Parse request body
    30→    const { worker_id } = await req.json()
    31→
    32→    if (!worker_id) {
    33→      return new Response(
    34→        JSON.stringify({ error: 'worker_id is required' }),
    35→        { status: 400, headers: { ...corsHeaders, 'Content-Type': 'application/json' } }
    36→      )
    37→    }
    38→
    39→    // Initialize Supabase client with service role key for admin access
    40→    const supabaseUrl = Deno.env.get('SUPABASE_URL')!
    41→    const supabaseServiceKey = Deno.env.get('SUPABASE_SERVICE_ROLE_KEY')!
    42→
    43→    const supabase = createClient(supabaseUrl, supabaseServiceKey)
    44→
    45→    // Calculate date 90 days ago
    46→    const ninetyDaysAgo = new Date(Date.now() - 90 * 24 * 60 * 60 * 1000).toISOString()
    47→
    48→    // Get completed bookings in last 90 days
    49→    const { data: bookings, error: bookingsError } = await supabase
    50→      .from('bookings')
    51→      .select('id, status, created_at')
    52→      .eq('worker_id', worker_id)
    53→      .gte('created_at', ninetyDaysAgo)
    54→
    55→    if (bookingsError) {
    56→      throw new Error(`Failed to fetch bookings: ${bookingsError.message}`)
    57→    }
    58→
    59→    // Calculate completion rate
    60→    const totalBookings = bookings?.length || 0
    61→    const completedBookings = bookings?.filter(b => b.status === 'completed').length || 0
    62→    const completionRate = totalBookings > 0 ? (completedBookings / totalBookings) * 100 : 100
    63→
    64→    // Get average rating from reviews
    65→    const { data: reviews, error: reviewsError } = await supabase
    66→      .from('reviews')
    67→      .select('rating')
    68→      .eq('worker_id', worker_id)
    69→
    70→    if (reviewsError) {
    71→      throw new Error(`Failed to fetch reviews: ${reviewsError.message}`)
    72→    }
    73→
    74→    const totalReviews = reviews?.length || 0
    75→    const avgRating = totalReviews > 0
    76→      ? reviews!.reduce((sum, r) => sum + r.rating, 0) / totalReviews
    77→      : 3.0
    78→
    79→    // Calculate reliability score
    80→    // Formula: (completion_rate * 0.5) + (avg_rating / 5 * 100 * 0.5)
    81→    // This gives equal weight to completion rate and rating
    82→    const ratingScore = (avgRating / 5) * 100
    83→    const reliabilityScore = (completionRate * 0.5) + (ratingScore * 0.5)
    84→
    85→    // Normalize to 1-5 scale
    86→    const normalizedScore = Math.max(1, Math.min(5, reliabilityScore / 20))
    87→
    88→    // Return the calculated score
    89→    // Note: The workers table doesn't have reliability_score column yet.
    90→    // When the column is added, uncomment the update code below:
    91→    /*
    92→    await supabase
    93→      .from('workers')
    94→      .update({
    95→        reliability_score: normalizedScore,
    96→        updated_at: new Date().toISOString()
    97→      })
    98→      .eq('id', worker_id)
    99→    */
   100→
   101→    return new Response(
   102→      JSON.stringify({
   103→        success: true,
   104→        worker_id,
   105→        reliability_score: Number(normalizedScore.toFixed(2)),
   106→        metrics: {
   107→          total_bookings: totalBookings,
   108→          completed_bookings: completedBookings,
   109→          completion_rate: Number(completionRate.toFixed(2)),
   110→          total_reviews: totalReviews,
   111→          avg_rating: Number(avgRating.toFixed(2)),
   112→          period_days: 90
   113→        }
   114→      }),
   115→      { headers: { ...corsHeaders, 'Content-Type': 'application/json' } }
   116→    )
   117→
   118→  } catch (error) {
   119→    return new Response(
   120→      JSON.stringify({
   121→        error: error.message || 'Internal server error'
   122→      }),
   123→      { status: 500, headers: { ...corsHeaders, 'Content-Type': 'application/json' } }
   124→    )
   125→  }
   126→})
   127→

entries.detail:
1→{
     2→  "feature": "Reliability Score Calculation",
     3→  "description": "# Reliability Score Calculation

Automated reliability scoring system that calculates worker scores (1-5 stars) based on attendance rate, punctuality rate, and average ratings from businesses. Uses weighted formula: 40% attendance, 30% punctuality, 30% ratings. Updates automatically after each completed job.

## Rationale
Reliability scores are the platform's key differentiator, addressing the no-show and inconsistent quality pain points. Scores provide businesses with confidence in worker dependability and incentivize workers to maintain high standards.

## User Stories
- As a business, I want to see worker reliability scores so that I can hire dependable workers
- As a worker, I want to earn a high score so that I can get more job opportunities
- As a worker, I want to understand my score calculation so that I can improve

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Reliability scores are calculated automatically after each job
- [ ] Score formula: 40% attendance + 30% punctuality + 30% ratings
- [ ] Scores range from 1.0 to 5.0 stars
- [ ] Scores update in real-time
- [ ] Score calculation is transparent and auditable
- [ ] Workers need 5+ completed jobs to have a reliable score
- [ ] Score history is tracked for trend analysis
",

entries.content:
---

## ✅ Planning Session Complete

I've completed the deep codebase investigation and created a comprehensive implementation plan for the **Reliability Score Calculation** feature.

### 📋 Planning Files Created

| File | Description |
|------|-------------|
| `implementation_plan.json` | 5 phases, 14 subtasks with dependencies and verification |
| `project_index.json` | Service architecture and infrastructure info |
| `context.json` | Code patterns, files to modify/create, existing implementations |
| `init.sh` | Development environment setup script |
| `build-progress.txt` | Session documentation and next steps |

### 🎯 Implementation Plan Overview

**Workflow Type:** Feature (multi-service with dependencies)

**Formula:** `40% attendance + 30% punctuality + 30% ratings`

#### Phase Breakdown:
1. **Database Schema Changes** (4 subtasks) - Add time tracking columns, create history table
2. **Backend Logic** (3 subtasks) - Update edge function, create queries and actions
3. **UI Components** (3 subtasks) - Create badge, breakdown, and history components
4. **Integration Pages** (2 subtasks) - Add scores to worker profile and business views
5. **Automation Triggers** (3 subtasks) - Database triggers and end-to-end verification

### 🔍 Key Discoveries

1. **Existing Implementation Found:** `supabase/functions/reliability-score/index.ts` exists but uses wrong formula (50/50) and has commented-out update code
2. **Schema Already Has:** `workers.reliability_score` column
3. **Schema Needs:** `actual_start_time`, `actual_end_time` for punctuality, and `reliability_score_history` table
4. **Tech Stack:** Next.js 14, TypeScript, Supabase (PostgreSQL), shadcn/ui

### 🚀 Next Steps

A **coder agent** will:
1. Start with **Phase 1, Subtask 1-1**: Add booking time tracking columns
2. Follow subtask order respecting dependencies
3. Complete verification before marking each subtask done

**DO NOT** push to remote - all work stays local until user review.
I'll implement subtask-1-1 to add `actual_start_time` and `actual_end_time` columns to the bookings table. Let me start by understanding the current state and following the established patterns.

entries.detail:
1→-- Add actual time tracking fields to bookings table
     2→-- This migration adds fields to track actual start and end times for reliability score calculation
     3→
     4→-- Add actual_start_time field (timestamptz for precise start time tracking)
     5→ALTER TABLE public.bookings
     6→  ADD COLUMN IF NOT EXISTS actual_start_time TIMESTAMPTZ;
     7→
     8→-- Add actual_end_time field (timestamptz for precise end time tracking)
     9→ALTER TABLE public.bookings
    10→  ADD COLUMN IF NOT EXISTS actual_end_time TIMESTAMPTZ;
    11→
    12→-- Add comments for documentation
    13→COMMENT ON COLUMN public.bookings.actual_start_time IS 'Actual timestamp when the worker started the job (used for reliability score calculation)';
    14→COMMENT ON COLUMN public.bookings.actual_end_time IS 'Actual timestamp when the worker completed the job (used for reliability score calculation)';
    15→
    16→-- Create index for actual_start_time queries (useful for filtering by actual start time)
    17→CREATE INDEX IF NOT EXISTS idx_bookings_actual_start_time ON public.bookings(actual_start_time);
    18→
    19→-- Create index for actual_end_time queries (useful for filtering by actual end time)
    20→CREATE INDEX IF NOT EXISTS idx_bookings_actual_end_time ON public.bookings(actual_end_time);
    21→

1→# Reliability Score Calculation
     2→
     3→Automated reliability scoring system that calculates worker scores (1-5 stars) based on attendance rate, punctuality rate, and average ratings from businesses. Uses weighted formula: 40% attendance, 30% punctuality, 30% ratings. Updates automatically after each completed job.
     4→
     5→## Rationale
     6→Reliability scores are the platform's key differentiator, addressing the no-show and inconsistent quality pain points. Scores provide businesses with confidence in worker dependability and incentivize workers to maintain high standards.
     7→
     8→## User Stories
     9→- As a business, I want to see worker reliability scores so that I can hire dependable workers
    10→- As a worker, I want to earn a high score so that I can get more job opportunities
    11→- As a worker, I want to understand my score calculation so that I can improve
    12→
    13→## Acceptance Criteria
    14→- [ ] Reliability scores are calculated automatically after each job
    15→- [ ] Score formula: 40% attendance + 30% punctuality + 30% ratings
    16→- [ ] Scores range from 1.0 to 5.0 stars
    17→- [ ] Scores update in real-time
    18→- [ ] Score calculation is transparent and auditable
    19→- [ ] Workers need 5+ completed jobs to have a reliable score
    20→- [ ] Score history is tracked for trend analysis
    21→

1→-- Create kyc_verifications table
     2→-- This table stores KYC (Know Your Customer) verification data for workers,
     3→-- including KTP (Indonesian ID card) information and uploaded documents.
     4→
     5→CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS public.kyc_verifications (
     6→  -- Primary key
     7→  id UUID DEFAULT gen_random_uuid() PRIMARY KEY,
     8→
     9→  -- Foreign key to workers table
    10→  worker_id UUID NOT NULL REFERENCES public.workers(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
    11→
    12→  -- KTP number (16-digit Indonesian ID number)
    13→  ktp_number TEXT NOT NULL UNIQUE,
    14→
    15→  -- URLs to uploaded images (stored in Supabase Storage)
    16→  ktp_image_url TEXT,
    17→  selfie_image_url TEXT,
    18→
    19→  -- Extracted data from KTP OCR (JSONB for flexible schema)
    20→  ktp_extracted_data JSONB,
    21→
    22→  -- Verification status: pending, verified, rejected
    23→  status TEXT NOT NULL DEFAULT 'pending' CHECK (status IN ('pending', 'verified', 'rejected')),
    24→
    25→  -- Rejection reason (nullable, only set when status is 'rejected')
    26→  rejection_reason TEXT,
    27→
    28→  -- Timestamps
    29→  submitted_at TIMESTAMPTZ NOT NULL DEFAULT NOW(),
    30→  verified_at TIMESTAMPTZ,
    31→  created_at TIMESTAMPTZ NOT NULL DEFAULT NOW(),
    32→  updated_at TIMESTAMPTZ NOT NULL DEFAULT NOW(),
    33→
    34→  -- Admin who verified the KYC (nullable)
    35→  verified_by UUID REFERENCES public.users(id) ON DELETE SET NULL
    36→);
    37→
    38→-- Create indexes for performance
    39→CREATE INDEX IF NOT EXISTS idx_kyc_verifications_worker_id ON public.kyc_verifications(worker_id);
    40→CREATE INDEX IF NOT EXISTS idx_kyc_verifications_status ON public.kyc_verifications(status);
    41→CREATE INDEX IF NOT EXISTS idx_kyc_verifications_ktp_number ON public.kyc_verifications(ktp_number);
    42→
    43→-- Add comment for documentation
    44→COMMENT ON TABLE public.kyc_verifications IS 'Stores KYC verification data for workers including KTP validation and document uploads';
    45→COMMENT ON COLUMN public.kyc_verifications.ktp_extracted_data IS 'JSONB field containing OCR-extracted data from KTP image (NIK, name, DOB, address, etc.)';
    46→COMMENT ON COLUMN public.kyc_verifications.status IS 'Verification status: pending (awaiting review), verified (approved), rejected (denied)';
    47→
    48→-- Enable Row Level Security (RLS)
    49→ALTER TABLE public.kyc_verifications ENABLE ROW LEVEL SECURITY;
    50→
    51→-- Create RLS policies
    52→-- Policy: Workers can view their own KYC data
    53→CREATE POLICY "Workers can view own KYC data"
    54→  ON public.kyc_verifications
    55→  FOR SELECT
    56→  USING (worker_id IN (SELECT id FROM public.workers WHERE user_id = auth.uid()));
    57→
    58→-- Policy: Workers can insert their own KYC data
    59→CREATE POLICY "Workers can insert own KYC data"
    60→  ON public.kyc_verifications
    61→  FOR INSERT
    62→  WITH CHECK (worker_id IN (SELECT id FROM public.workers WHERE user_id = auth.uid()));
    63→
    64→-- Policy: Workers can update their own KYC data (only before verification)
    65→CREATE POLICY "Workers can update own unverified KYC data"
    66→  ON public.kyc_verifications
    67→  FOR UPDATE
    68→  USING (
    69→    worker_id IN (SELECT id FROM public.workers WHERE user_id = auth.uid())
    70→    AND status = 'pending'
    71→  )
    72→  WITH CHECK (
    73→    worker_id IN (SELECT id FROM public.workers WHERE user_id = auth.uid())
    74→    AND status = 'pending'
    75→  );
    76→
    77→-- Policy: Admins can view all KYC data
    78→CREATE POLICY "Admins can view all KYC data"
    79→  ON public.kyc_verifications
    80→  FOR SELECT
    81→  USING (
    82→    EXISTS (
    83→      SELECT 1 FROM public.users
    84→      WHERE id = auth.uid() AND role = 'admin'
    85→    )
    86→  );
    87→
    88→-- Policy: Admins can update all KYC data
    89→CREATE POLICY "Admins can update all KYC data"
    90→  ON public.kyc_verifications
    91→  FOR UPDATE
    92→  USING (
    93→    EXISTS (
    94→      SELECT 1 FROM public.users
    95→      WHERE id = auth.uid() AND role = 'admin'
    96→    )
    97→  )
    98→  WITH CHECK (
    99→    EXISTS (
   100→      SELECT 1 FROM public.users
   101→      WHERE id = auth.uid() AND role = 'admin'
   102→    )
   103→  );
   104→
   105→-- Create trigger to update updated_at timestamp
   106→CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION update_kyc_verifications_updated_at()
   107→RETURNS TRIGGER AS $$
   108→BEGIN
   109→  NEW.updated_at = NOW();
   110→  RETURN NEW;
   111→END;
   112→$$ LANGUAGE plpgsql;
   113→
   114→CREATE TRIGGER set_kyc_verifications_updated_at
   115→  BEFORE UPDATE ON public.kyc_verifications
   116→  FOR EACH ROW
   117→  EXECUTE FUNCTION update_kyc_verifications_updated_at();
   118→

1→-- Create reliability_score_history table
     2→-- This table stores historical reliability scores for workers, tracking score changes
     3→-- over time to enable trend analysis and provide transparent audit trails.
     4→
     5→CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS public.reliability_score_history (
     6→  -- Primary key
     7→  id UUID DEFAULT gen_random_uuid() PRIMARY KEY,
     8→
     9→  -- Foreign key to workers table
    10→  worker_id UUID NOT NULL REFERENCES public.workers(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
    11→
    12→  -- Reliability score (1.0 to 5.0 stars)
    13→  score NUMERIC(3, 2) NOT NULL CHECK (score >= 1.0 AND score <= 5.0),
    14→
    15→  -- Score components (for transparency and audit trail)
    16→  attendance_rate NUMERIC(5, 2) NOT NULL CHECK (attendance_rate >= 0 AND attendance_rate <= 100),
    17→  punctuality_rate NUMERIC(5, 2) NOT NULL CHECK (punctuality_rate >= 0 AND punctuality_rate <= 100),
    18→  avg_rating NUMERIC(3, 2) NOT NULL CHECK (avg_rating >= 1.0 AND avg_rating <= 5.0),
    19→
    20→  -- Number of completed jobs at time of score calculation
    21→  -- (scores are only considered reliable after 5+ completed jobs)
    22→  completed_jobs_count INTEGER NOT NULL DEFAULT 0,
    23→
    24→  -- Timestamp when score was calculated
    25→  calculated_at TIMESTAMPTZ NOT NULL DEFAULT NOW(),
    26→  created_at TIMESTAMPTZ NOT NULL DEFAULT NOW()
    27→);
    28→
    29→-- Create indexes for performance
    30→CREATE INDEX IF NOT EXISTS idx_reliability_score_history_worker_id ON public.reliability_score_history(worker_id);
    31→CREATE INDEX IF NOT EXISTS idx_reliability_score_history_calculated_at ON public.reliability_score_history(calculated_at DESC);
    32→CREATE INDEX IF NOT EXISTS idx_reliability_score_history_worker_calculated ON public.reliability_score_history(worker_id, calculated_at DESC);
    33→
    34→-- Add comment for documentation
    35→COMMENT ON TABLE public.reliability_score_history IS 'Stores historical reliability scores for workers, tracking score changes over time for trend analysis and audit trails';
    36→COMMENT ON COLUMN public.reliability_score_history.score IS 'Overall reliability score from 1.0 to 5.0 stars, calculated as 40% attendance + 30% punctuality + 30% ratings';
    37→COMMENT ON COLUMN public.reliability_score_history.attendance_rate IS 'Percentage of jobs the worker attended (did not no-show)';
    38→COMMENT ON COLUMN public.reliability_score_history.punctuality_rate IS 'Percentage of jobs the worker arrived on time for';
    39→COMMENT ON COLUMN public.reliability_score_history.avg_rating IS 'Average rating given by businesses across all completed jobs (1-5 scale)';
    40→COMMENT ON COLUMN public.reliability_score_history.completed_jobs_count IS 'Number of completed jobs at time of calculation. Scores are only considered reliable after 5+ jobs.';
    41→COMMENT ON COLUMN public.reliability_score_history.calculated_at IS 'Timestamp when the score was calculated';
    42→
    43→-- Enable Row Level Security (RLS)
    44→ALTER TABLE public.reliability_score_history ENABLE ROW LEVEL SECURITY;
    45→
    46→-- Create RLS policies
    47→-- Policy: Workers can view their own score history
    48→CREATE POLICY "Workers can view own reliability score history"
    49→  ON public.reliability_score_history
    50→  FOR SELECT
    51→  USING (worker_id IN (SELECT id FROM public.workers WHERE user_id = auth.uid()));
    52→
    53→-- Policy: Admins can view all reliability score history
    54→CREATE POLICY "Admins can view all reliability score history"
    55→  ON public.reliability_score_history
    56→  FOR SELECT
    57→  USING (
    58→    EXISTS (
    59→      SELECT 1 FROM public.users
    60→      WHERE id = auth.uid() AND role = 'admin'
    61→    )
    62→  );
    63→

## Subtask 1-2 Completed ✓

**Summary of changes:**

1. **Created migration file:** `supabase/migrations/20260222_create_reliability_score_history.sql`

2. **Table structure:**
   - `id` - UUID primary key
   - `worker_id` - Foreign key to workers table (CASCADE delete)
   - `score` - NUMERIC(3,2) with CHECK constraint (1.0-5.0)
   - `attendance_rate` - NUMERIC(5,2) with CHECK constraint (0-100)
   - `punctuality_rate` - NUMERIC(5,2) with CHECK constraint (0-100)
   - `avg_rating` - NUMERIC(3,2) with CHECK constraint (1.0-5.0)
   - `completed_jobs_count` - INTEGER (tracks 5+ job threshold for reliability)
   - `calculated_at` - TIMESTAMPTZ (when score was calculated)
   - `created_at` - TIMESTAMPTZ (record creation timestamp)

3. **Performance indexes:**
   - `idx_reliability_score_history_worker_id`
   - `idx_reliability_score_history_calculated_at` (DESC)
   - `idx_reliability_score_history_worker_calculated` (composite)

4. **Security (RLS policies):**
   - Workers can view their own score history
   - Admins can view all score history

5. **Documentation:** Comprehensive COMMENT statements for table and columns

**Commit:** `c790733`

**Quality Checklist:**
- ✅ Follows patterns from reference file (kyc_verifications)
- ✅ No console.log/print debugging statements
- ✅ Error handling in place (CHECK constraints, foreign key constraints)
- ✅ Clean commit with descriptive message

**Note:** The RLS policies were already included in this migration (following the pattern from kyc_verifications), so subtask 1-3 may be redundant or can be skipped.

1→# Reliability Score Calculation

     3→Automated reliability scoring system that calculates worker scores (1-5 stars) based on attendance rate, punctuality rate, and average ratings from businesses. Uses weighted formula: 40% attendance, 30% punctuality, 30% ratings. Updates automatically after each completed job.
     4→
     5→## Rationale

    10→- As a worker, I want to earn a high score so that I can get more job opportunities

    12→

    17→- [ ] Scores update in real-time
    18→- [ ] Score calculation is transparent and auditable
    19→- [ ] Workers need 5+ completed jobs to have a reliable score
    20→- [ ] Score history is tracked for trend analysis

entries.detail:
1→-- Add RLS Policies for Workers Table
     2→-- This migration adds Row Level Security (RLS) policies to the workers table
     3→-- to protect KYC-related data and personal information
     4→
     5→-- Enable Row Level Security (RLS) on workers table
     6→ALTER TABLE public.workers ENABLE ROW LEVEL SECURITY;
     7→
     8→-- Policy: Workers can view their own profile data
     9→CREATE POLICY "Workers can view own profile"
    10→  ON public.workers
    11→  FOR SELECT
    12→  USING (user_id = auth.uid());
    13→
    14→-- Policy: Workers can insert their own profile (on registration)
    15→CREATE POLICY "Workers can insert own profile"
    16→  ON public.workers
    17→  FOR INSERT
    18→  WITH CHECK (user_id = auth.uid());
    19→
    20→-- Policy: Workers can update their own profile data
    21→-- But restrict updates to certain fields when KYC is verified
    22→CREATE POLICY "Workers can update own profile"
    23→  ON public.workers
    24→  FOR UPDATE
    25→  USING (user_id = auth.uid())
    26→  WITH CHECK (
    27→    user_id = auth.uid()
    28→    -- Allow updates to most fields, but prevent modifying KYC status once verified
    29→    AND (
    30→      -- Allow any updates if not verified
    31→      kyc_status IN ('unverified', 'pending', 'rejected')
    32→      -- If verified, only allow safe field updates
    33→      OR (
    34→        kyc_status = 'verified'
    35→        AND NOT (
    36→          -- Prevent changing kyc_status
    37→          OLD.kyc_status IS DISTINCT FROM NEW.kyc_status
    38→          -- Prevent changing reliability_score (admin only)
    39→          OR OLD.reliability_score IS DISTINCT FROM NEW.reliability_score
    40→        )
    41→      )
    42→    )
    43→  );
    44→
    45→-- Policy: Admins can view all worker profiles
    46→CREATE POLICY "Admins can view all worker profiles"
    47→  ON public.workers
    48→  FOR SELECT
    49→  USING (
    50→    EXISTS (
    51→      SELECT 1 FROM public.users
    52→      WHERE id = auth.uid() AND role = 'admin'
    53→    )
    54→  );
    55→
    56→-- Policy: Admins can update all worker profiles
    57→CREATE POLICY "Admins can update all worker profiles"
    58→  ON public.workers
    59→  FOR UPDATE
    60→  USING (
    61→    EXISTS (
    62→      SELECT 1 FROM public.users
    63→      WHERE id = auth.uid() AND role = 'admin'
    64→    )
    65→  )
    66→  WITH CHECK (
    67→    EXISTS (
    68→      SELECT 1 FROM public.users
    69→      WHERE id = auth.uid() AND role = 'admin'
    70→    )
    71→  );
    72→
    73→-- Policy: Admins can insert worker profiles (for manual worker creation)
    74→CREATE POLICY "Admins can insert worker profiles"
    75→  ON public.workers
    76→  FOR INSERT
    77→  WITH CHECK (
    78→    EXISTS (
    79→      SELECT 1 FROM public.users
    80→      WHERE id = auth.uid() AND role = 'admin'
    81→    )
    82→  );
    83→
    84→-- Policy: Businesses can view verified worker profiles
    85→-- This allows businesses to search and view workers who have completed KYC
    86→CREATE POLICY "Businesses can view verified worker profiles"
    87→  ON public.workers
    88→  FOR SELECT
    89→  USING (
    90→    EXISTS (
    91→      SELECT 1 FROM public.users
    92→      WHERE id = auth.uid() AND role = 'business'
    93→    )
    94→    AND kyc_status = 'verified'
    95→  );
    96→
    97→-- Add comments for documentation
    98→COMMENT ON POLICY "Workers can view own profile" ON public.workers IS 'Allows authenticated workers to view their own profile data';
    99→COMMENT ON POLICY "Workers can insert own profile" ON public.workers IS 'Allows authenticated workers to create their profile on registration';
   100→COMMENT ON POLICY "Workers can update own profile" ON public.workers IS 'Allows workers to update their own profile with restrictions on kyc_status and reliability_score when verified';
   101→COMMENT ON POLICY "Admins can view all worker profiles" ON public.workers IS 'Allows admins to view all worker profiles for management';
   102→COMMENT ON POLICY "Admins can update all worker profiles" ON public.workers IS 'Allows admins to update any worker profile including kyc_status and reliability_score';
   103→COMMENT ON POLICY "Admins can insert worker profiles" ON public.workers IS 'Allows admins to manually create worker profiles';
   104→COMMENT ON POLICY "Businesses can view verified worker profiles" ON public.workers IS 'Allows businesses to view only verified worker profiles for hiring';
   105→

entries.detail:
1→-- Migration: Add Row Level Security (RLS) policies for bookings table
     2→-- Date: 2026-02-22
     3→-- Description: Implement security policies to ensure workers and businesses can only access their own bookings
     4→
     5→-- Enable Row Level Security on bookings table
     6→ALTER TABLE bookings
     7→ENABLE ROW LEVEL SECURITY;
     8→
     9→-- ============================================================================
    10→-- WORKER POLICIES
    11→-- Workers can view, insert, and update their own bookings
    12→-- ============================================================================
    13→
    14→-- Policy: Workers can view their own bookings
    15→CREATE POLICY "Workers can view their own bookings"
    16→ON bookings FOR SELECT
    17→USING (
    18→  worker_id IN (
    19→    SELECT id FROM workers WHERE user_id = auth.uid()
    20→  )
    21→);
    22→
    23→-- Policy: Workers can insert bookings (apply for jobs)
    24→CREATE POLICY "Workers can create their own bookings"
    25→ON bookings FOR INSERT
    26→WITH CHECK (
    27→  worker_id IN (
    28→    SELECT id FROM workers WHERE user_id = auth.uid()
    29→  )
    30→);
    31→
    32→-- Policy: Workers can update their own bookings (cancel pending applications)
    33→CREATE POLICY "Workers can update their own bookings"
    34→ON bookings FOR UPDATE
    35→USING (
    36→  worker_id IN (
    37→    SELECT id FROM workers WHERE user_id = auth.uid()
    38→  )
    39→)
    40→WITH CHECK (
    41→  worker_id IN (
    42→    SELECT id FROM workers WHERE user_id = auth.uid()
    43→  )
    44→  AND status = 'pending' -- Can only cancel pending bookings
    45→);
    46→
    47→-- ============================================================================
    48→-- BUSINESS POLICIES
    49→-- Businesses can view and update bookings for their jobs
    50→-- ============================================================================
    51→
    52→-- Policy: Businesses can view bookings for their jobs
    53→CREATE POLICY "Businesses can view their job bookings"
    54→ON bookings FOR SELECT
    55→USING (
    56→  business_id IN (
    57→    SELECT id FROM businesses WHERE user_id = auth.uid()
    58→  )
    59→);
    60→
    61→-- Policy: Businesses can update booking status (accept/reject)
    62→CREATE POLICY "Businesses can update booking status"
    63→ON bookings FOR UPDATE
    64→USING (
    65→  business_id IN (
    66→    SELECT id FROM businesses WHERE user_id = auth.uid()
    67→  )
    68→)
    69→WITH CHECK (
    70→  business_id IN (
    71→    SELECT id FROM businesses WHERE user_id = auth.uid()
    72→  )
    73→  AND status IN ('pending', 'accepted', 'rejected', 'cancelled', 'completed', 'no_show')
    74→);
    75→
    76→-- ============================================================================
    77→-- ADMIN POLICIES
    78→-- Admins have full access to all bookings for auditing and support
    79→-- ============================================================================
    80→
    81→-- Policy: Admins can view all bookings
    82→CREATE POLICY "Admins can view all bookings"
    83→ON bookings FOR SELECT

    11→-- Workers can view their own reliability score history
    12→-- ============================================================================

    14→-- Policy: Workers can view their own score history

## Subtask 1-3 Completed ✓

I've successfully added RLS policies for the `reliability_score_history` table. Here's what was implemented:

### Migration File Created
`supabase/migrations/20260222_add_reliability_score_rls.sql`

### RLS Policies
1. **Workers can view their own score history** - Allows authenticated workers to see only their reliability score history
2. **Admins can view all score history** - Admins have full access for auditing and support
3. **Service role can insert records** - Only the backend service role can create new history entries

### Security Features
- Score history is **immutable** - no UPDATE or DELETE policies ensure data integrity
- Read-only access for workers and admins
- Automated scoring system can insert new history entries
- Comprehensive documentation and security notes

### Changes Committed
- `b8df518` - Add RLS policies for reliability_score_history table
- `4f5a4bd` - Update implementation plan - mark subtask-1-3 as completed

The implementation follows the patterns from the existing RLS policies (especially the bookings RLS policies) and ensures proper data isolation and auditability for reliability score tracking.
I'll work on subtask-1-4 to regenerate TypeScript types from the updated schema. Let me start by verifying my location and reading the necessary files.

entries.detail:
1→-- Create reliability_score_history table
     2→-- This table stores historical reliability scores for workers, tracking score changes
     3→-- over time to enable trend analysis and provide transparent audit trails.
     4→
     5→CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS public.reliability_score_history (
     6→  -- Primary key
     7→  id UUID DEFAULT gen_random_uuid() PRIMARY KEY,
     8→
     9→  -- Foreign key to workers table
    10→  worker_id UUID NOT NULL REFERENCES public.workers(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
    11→
    12→  -- Reliability score (1.0 to 5.0 stars)
    13→  score NUMERIC(3, 2) NOT NULL CHECK (score >= 1.0 AND score <= 5.0),
    14→
    15→  -- Score components (for transparency and audit trail)
    16→  attendance_rate NUMERIC(5, 2) NOT NULL CHECK (attendance_rate >= 0 AND attendance_rate <= 100),
    17→  punctuality_rate NUMERIC(5, 2) NOT NULL CHECK (punctuality_rate >= 0 AND punctuality_rate <= 100),
    18→  avg_rating NUMERIC(3, 2) NOT NULL CHECK (avg_rating >= 1.0 AND avg_rating <= 5.0),
    19→
    20→  -- Number of completed jobs at time of score calculation
    21→  -- (scores are only considered reliable after 5+ completed jobs)
    22→  completed_jobs_count INTEGER NOT NULL DEFAULT 0,
    23→
    24→  -- Timestamp when score was calculated
    25→  calculated_at TIMESTAMPTZ NOT NULL DEFAULT NOW(),
    26→  created_at TIMESTAMPTZ NOT NULL DEFAULT NOW()
    27→);
    28→
    29→-- Create indexes for performance
    30→CREATE INDEX IF NOT EXISTS idx_reliability_score_history_worker_id ON public.reliability_score_history(worker_id);
    31→CREATE INDEX IF NOT EXISTS idx_reliability_score_history_calculated_at ON public.reliability_score_history(calculated_at DESC);
    32→CREATE INDEX IF NOT EXISTS idx_reliability_score_history_worker_calculated ON public.reliability_score_history(worker_id, calculated_at DESC);
    33→
    34→-- Add comment for documentation
    35→COMMENT ON TABLE public.reliability_score_history IS 'Stores historical reliability scores for workers, tracking score changes over time for trend analysis and audit trails';
    36→COMMENT ON COLUMN public.reliability_score_history.score IS 'Overall reliability score from 1.0 to 5.0 stars, calculated as 40% attendance + 30% punctuality + 30% ratings';
    37→COMMENT ON COLUMN public.reliability_score_history.attendance_rate IS 'Percentage of jobs the worker attended (did not no-show)';
    38→COMMENT ON COLUMN public.reliability_score_history.punctuality_rate IS 'Percentage of jobs the worker arrived on time for';
    39→COMMENT ON COLUMN public.reliability_score_history.avg_rating IS 'Average rating given by businesses across all completed jobs (1-5 scale)';
    40→COMMENT ON COLUMN public.reliability_score_history.completed_jobs_count IS 'Number of completed jobs at time of calculation. Scores are only considered reliable after 5+ jobs.';
    41→COMMENT ON COLUMN public.reliability_score_history.calculated_at IS 'Timestamp when the score was calculated';
    42→
    43→-- Enable Row Level Security (RLS)
    44→ALTER TABLE public.reliability_score_history ENABLE ROW LEVEL SECURITY;
    45→
    46→-- Create RLS policies
    47→-- Policy: Workers can view their own score history
    48→CREATE POLICY "Workers can view own reliability score history"
    49→  ON public.reliability_score_history
    50→  FOR SELECT
    51→  USING (worker_id IN (SELECT id FROM public.workers WHERE user_id = auth.uid()));
    52→
    53→-- Policy: Admins can view all reliability score history
    54→CREATE POLICY "Admins can view all reliability score history"
    55→  ON public.reliability_score_history
    56→  FOR SELECT
    57→  USING (
    58→    EXISTS (
    59→      SELECT 1 FROM public.users
    60→      WHERE id = auth.uid() AND role = 'admin'
    61→    )
    62→  );
    63→

entries.detail:
1→# Reliability Score Calculation
     2→
     3→Automated reliability scoring system that calculates worker scores (1-5 stars) based on attendance rate, punctuality rate, and average ratings from businesses. Uses weighted formula: 40% attendance, 30% punctuality, 30% ratings. Updates automatically after each completed job.
     4→
     5→## Rationale
     6→Reliability scores are the platform's key differentiator, addressing the no-show and inconsistent quality pain points. Scores provide businesses with confidence in worker dependability and incentivize workers to maintain high standards.
     7→
     8→## User Stories
     9→- As a business, I want to see worker reliability scores so that I can hire dependable workers
    10→- As a worker, I want to earn a high score so that I can get more job opportunities
    11→- As a worker, I want to understand my score calculation so that I can improve
    12→
    13→## Acceptance Criteria
    14→- [ ] Reliability scores are calculated automatically after each job
    15→- [ ] Score formula: 40% attendance + 30% punctuality + 30% ratings
    16→- [ ] Scores range from 1.0 to 5.0 stars
    17→- [ ] Scores update in real-time
    18→- [ ] Score calculation is transparent and auditable
    19→- [ ] Workers need 5+ completed jobs to have a reliable score
    20→- [ ] Score history is tracked for trend analysis
    21→

entries.content:
Now I understand the schema. The bookings table has:
- `start_date` and `end_date` (DATE columns for scheduled times)
- `actual_start_time` and `actual_end_time` (TIMESTAMPTZ columns added for tracking actual times)

For punctuality, I'll define it as:
- **On-time arrival**: actual_start_time is on or before the scheduled start_date (plus a reasonable grace period)
- **On-time completion**: actual_end_time is on or before the scheduled end_date

1→// ============================================================================
     2→// Reliability Score Edge Function
     3→// ============================================================================
     4→// Calculates and updates worker reliability scores based on:
     5→// - Booking completion rate (attendance)
     6→// - Average rating from reviews
     7→// - Recent activity (last 90 days)
     8→//
     9→// POST /functions/v1/reliability-score
    10→// Body: { worker_id: string }
    11→// ============================================================================
    12→
    13→import { serve } from 'https://deno.land/std@0.168.0/http/server.ts'
    14→import { createClient } from 'https://esm.sh/@supabase/supabase-js@2.38.4'
    15→
    16→// CORS headers for browser requests
    17→const corsHeaders = {
    18→  'Access-Control-Allow-Origin': '*',
    19→  'Access-Control-Allow-Headers': 'authorization, x-client-info, apikey, content-type',
    20→}
    21→
    22→serve(async (req) => {
    23→  // Handle CORS preflight
    24→  if (req.method === 'OPTIONS') {
    25→    return new Response('ok', { headers: corsHeaders })
    26→  }
    27→
    28→  try {
    29→    // Parse request body
    30→    const { worker_id } = await req.json()
    31→
    32→    if (!worker_id) {
    33→      return new Response(
    34→        JSON.stringify({ error: 'worker_id is required' }),
    35→        { status: 400, headers: { ...corsHeaders, 'Content-Type': 'application/json' } }
    36→      )
    37→    }
    38→
    39→    // Initialize Supabase client with service role key for admin access
    40→    const supabaseUrl = Deno.env.get('SUPABASE_URL')!
    41→    const supabaseServiceKey = Deno.env.get('SUPABASE_SERVICE_ROLE_KEY')!
    42→
    43→    const supabase = createClient(supabaseUrl, supabaseServiceKey)
    44→
    45→    // Calculate date 90 days ago
    46→    const ninetyDaysAgo = new Date(Date.now() - 90 * 24 * 60 * 60 * 1000).toISOString()
    47→
    48→    // Get completed bookings in last 90 days
    49→    const { data: bookings, error: bookingsError } = await supabase
    50→      .from('bookings')
    51→      .select('id, status, created_at')
    52→      .eq('worker_id', worker_id)
    53→      .gte('created_at', ninetyDaysAgo)
    54→
    55→    if (bookingsError) {
    56→      throw new Error(`Failed to fetch bookings: ${bookingsError.message}`)
    57→    }
    58→
    59→    // Calculate completion rate
    60→    const totalBookings = bookings?.length || 0
    61→    const completedBookings = bookings?.filter(b => b.status === 'completed').length || 0
    62→    const completionRate = totalBookings > 0 ? (completedBookings / totalBookings) * 100 : 100
    63→
    64→    // Get average rating from reviews
    65→    const { data: reviews, error: reviewsError } = await supabase
    66→      .from('reviews')
    67→      .select('rating')
    68→      .eq('worker_id', worker_id)
    69→
    70→    if (reviewsError) {
    71→      throw new Error(`Failed to fetch reviews: ${reviewsError.message}`)
    72→    }
    73→
    74→    const totalReviews = reviews?.length || 0
    75→    const avgRating = totalReviews > 0
    76→      ? reviews!.reduce((sum, r) => sum + r.rating, 0) / totalReviews
    77→      : 3.0
    78→
    79→    // Calculate reliability score
    80→    // Formula: (completion_rate * 0.5) + (avg_rating / 5 * 100 * 0.5)
    81→    // This gives equal weight to completion rate and rating
    82→    const ratingScore = (avgRating / 5) * 100
    83→    const reliabilityScore = (completionRate * 0.5) + (ratingScore * 0.5)
    84→
    85→    // Normalize to 1-5 scale
    86→    const normalizedScore = Math.max(1, Math.min(5, reliabilityScore / 20))
    87→
    88→    // Return the calculated score
    89→    // Note: The workers table doesn't have reliability_score column yet.
    90→    // When the column is added, uncomment the update code below:
    91→    /*
    92→    await supabase
    93→      .from('workers')
    94→      .update({
    95→        reliability_score: normalizedScore,
    96→        updated_at: new Date().toISOString()
    97→      })
    98→      .eq('id', worker_id)
    99→    */
   100→
   101→    return new Response(
   102→      JSON.stringify({
   103→        success: true,
   104→        worker_id,
   105→        reliability_score: Number(normalizedScore.toFixed(2)),
   106→        metrics: {
   107→          total_bookings: totalBookings,
   108→          completed_bookings: completedBookings,
   109→          completion_rate: Number(completionRate.toFixed(2)),
   110→          total_reviews: totalReviews,
   111→          avg_rating: Number(avgRating.toFixed(2)),
   112→          period_days: 90
   113→        }
   114→      }),
   115→      { headers: { ...corsHeaders, 'Content-Type': 'application/json' } }
   116→    )
   117→
   118→  } catch (error) {
   119→    return new Response(
   120→      JSON.stringify({
   121→        error: error.message || 'Internal server error'
   122→      }),
   123→      { status: 500, headers: { ...corsHeaders, 'Content-Type': 'application/json' } }
   124→    )
   125→  }
   126→})
   127→

entries.content:
I have successfully completed **subtask-2-1**. Here's a summary of the changes:

## Changes Made

### 1. Updated `supabase/functions/reliability-score/index.ts`
- **Changed formula from 50/50 to 40/30/30:**
  - 40% Attendance (booking completion rate)
  - 30% Punctuality (on-time arrival/completion)
  - 30% Ratings (average review score)

- **Added punctuality calculation:**
  - Compares `actual_start_time` vs `start_date` (with 1-hour grace period)
  - Compares `actual_end_time` vs `end_date` (with 1-hour grace period)
  - Defaults to 100% if no time data available

- **Enabled the update code** that was previously commented out to persist scores to the workers table

- **Added score history recording** to `reliability_score_history` table

### 2. Created `supabase/migrations/20260222_add_reliability_score_to_workers.sql`
- Added `reliability_score` column to workers table (NUMERIC(3,2) with CHECK constraint 1.0-5.0)
- Added index for sorting workers by reliability score
- Added documentation comments

## Verification

The edge function now:
- Calculates scores using the correct 40/30/30 formula
- Records score history for trend tracking
- Updates the worker's reliability score in the workers table
- Returns detailed metrics including attendance_rate, punctuality_rate, and avg_rating

To test the endpoint once Supabase is running:
```bash
curl -X POST http://localhost:54321/functions/v1/reliability-score \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{"worker_id": "test-worker-id"}'
```

     3→Automated reliability scoring system that calculates worker scores (1-5 stars) based on attendance rate, punctuality rate, and average ratings from businesses. Uses weighted formula: 40% attendance, 30% punctuality, 30% ratings. Updates automatically after each completed job.
     4→
     5→## Rationale
     6→Reliability scores are the platform's key differentiator, addressing the no-show and inconsistent quality pain points. Scores provide businesses with confidence in worker dependability and incentivize workers to maintain high standards.

     8→## User Stories
     9→- As a business, I want to see worker reliability scores so that I can hire dependable workers
    10→- As a worker, I want to earn a high score so that I can get more job opportunities
    11→- As a worker, I want to understand my score calculation so that I can improve
    12→

    15→- [ ] Score formula: 40% attendance + 30% punctuality + 30% ratings
    16→- [ ] Scores range from 1.0 to 5.0 stars
    17→- [ ] Scores update in real-time
    18→- [ ] Score calculation is transparent and auditable
    19→- [ ] Workers need 5+ completed jobs to have a reliable score
    20→- [ ] Score history is tracked for trend analysis

Good, I'm in the correct location. Now let me analyze the file.

Looking at the code, I can see that:

1. **`acceptApplication`** (lines 233-270) - changes booking status from "pending" to "accepted"
2. **`completeBooking`** (lines 319-363) - the "job completion flow" that changes status to "completed"

The `completeBooking` function **already has the score calculation implemented** at lines 353-357:

```typescript
// Trigger reliability score calculation for the worker
// This is a backup to the database trigger - ensures score is always calculated
if (booking.worker_id) {
  await calculateWorkerScore(booking.worker_id)
}
```

The score calculation is properly integrated into the job completion flow. The function:
1. Verifies the booking exists and belongs to the business
2. Checks the booking can be completed (must be "accepted" or "in_progress")
3. Updates the booking status to "completed"
4. **Triggers the reliability score calculation for the worker** ✓

The implementation follows the existing patterns:
- Uses `calculateWorkerScore` from `./reliability-score` (already imported at line 5)
- Has proper error handling with try-catch
- Uses the same pattern as other functions in the file
- Has clear comments explaining the purpose

Since the score calculation is already properly implemented in the `completeBooking` function (the job completion flow), this subtask is **already complete**.

Perfect! I've completed subtask-5-2. Here's a summary:

## Subtask 5-2: Add score calculation to job completion flow ✅

### Status: ALREADY COMPLETE - VERIFIED

The `completeBooking` function in `lib/actions/job-applications.ts` (lines 319-363) **already includes the score calculation**:

```typescript
// Update the booking status to completed
const { data, error } = await supabase
  .from("bookings")
  .update({ status: "completed" })
  .eq("id", bookingId)
  .eq("business_id", businessId)
  .select()
  .single()

// ...

// Trigger reliability score calculation for the worker
// This is a backup to the database trigger - ensures score is always calculated
if (booking.worker_id) {
  await calculateWorkerScore(booking.worker_id)
}
```

### Implementation Details:
- **Import**: `calculateWorkerScore` is imported from `./reliability-score` (line 5)
- **Call Location**: After booking status is successfully updated to "completed"
- **Purpose**: Serves as a backup to the database trigger from subtask-5-1
- **Pattern**: Follows the same return type pattern (`{success, error?, data?}`) as other functions
- **Error Handling**: Wrapped in try-catch with Indonesian error messages

### Files Updated:
1. ✅ `implementation_plan.json` - Marked subtask-5-2 as "completed"
2. ✅ `build-progress.txt` - Documented verification results

No code changes were needed since the implementation was already complete. The subtask required verification that score calculation exists in the job completion flow, which it does.

entries.detail:
1→# Reliability Score Calculation
     2→
     3→Automated reliability scoring system that calculates worker scores (1-5 stars) based on attendance rate, punctuality rate, and average ratings from businesses. Uses weighted formula: 40% attendance, 30% punctuality, 30% ratings. Updates automatically after each completed job.
     4→
     5→## Rationale
     6→Reliability scores are the platform's key differentiator, addressing the no-show and inconsistent quality pain points. Scores provide businesses with confidence in worker dependability and incentivize workers to maintain high standards.
     7→
     8→## User Stories
     9→- As a business, I want to see worker reliability scores so that I can hire dependable workers
    10→- As a worker, I want to earn a high score so that I can get more job opportunities
    11→- As a worker, I want to understand my score calculation so that I can improve
    12→
    13→## Acceptance Criteria
    14→- [ ] Reliability scores are calculated automatically after each job
    15→- [ ] Score formula: 40% attendance + 30% punctuality + 30% ratings
    16→- [ ] Scores range from 1.0 to 5.0 stars
    17→- [ ] Scores update in real-time
    18→- [ ] Score calculation is transparent and auditable
    19→- [ ] Workers need 5+ completed jobs to have a reliable score
    20→- [ ] Score history is tracked for trend analysis
    21→

entries.detail:
1→import { supabase } from '../client'
     2→import type { Database } from '../types'
     3→
     4→type WorkersRow = Database['public']['Tables']['workers']['Row']
     5→type WorkersUpdate = Database['public']['Tables']['workers']['Update']
     6→type ReliabilityScoreHistoryRow = Database['public']['Tables']['reliability_score_history']['Row']
     7→type ReliabilityScoreHistoryInsert = Database['public']['Tables']['reliability_score_history']['Insert']
     8→
     9→export interface ReliabilityScoreBreakdown {
    10→  score: number
    11→  attendance_rate: number
    12→  punctuality_rate: number
    13→  avg_rating: number
    14→  completed_jobs_count: number
    15→}
    16→
    17→/**
    18→ * Calculate reliability score based on attendance, punctuality, and ratings
    19→ * Formula: 40% attendance + 30% punctuality + 30% ratings
    20→ */
    21→export async function calculateScore(workerId: string): Promise<ReliabilityScoreBreakdown | null> {
    22→  // Get all completed bookings for the worker
    23→  const { data: bookings, error: bookingsError } = await supabase
    24→    .from('bookings')
    25→    .select('*')
    26→    .eq('worker_id', workerId)
    27→    .eq('status', 'completed')
    28→
    29→  if (bookingsError) {
    30→    throw new Error(`Failed to fetch worker bookings: ${bookingsError.message}`)
    31→  }
    32→
    33→  if (!bookings || bookings.length === 0) {
    34→    return null
    35→  }
    36→
    37→  const completedJobsCount = bookings.length
    38→
    39→  // Calculate attendance rate
    40→  // All completed bookings count as attended (they weren't cancelled)
    41→  const attendance_rate = 1.0
    42→
    43→  // Calculate punctuality rate
    44→  // Punctual if actual_start_time is before or equal to scheduled start_time
    45→  let onTimeCount = 0
    46→  const bookingsWithTimes = bookings.filter(
    47→    b => b.actual_start_time !== null && b.start_date !== null
    48→  )
    49→
    50→  bookingsWithTimes.forEach(booking => {
    51→    const actualStart = new Date(booking.actual_start_time!)
    52→    const scheduledStart = new Date(booking.start_date)
    53→    if (actualStart <= scheduledStart) {
    54→      onTimeCount++
    55→    }
    56→  })
    57→
    58→  const punctuality_rate = bookingsWithTimes.length > 0
    59→    ? onTimeCount / bookingsWithTimes.length
    60→    : 1.0
    61→
    62→  // Calculate average rating
    63→  const { data: reviews, error: reviewsError } = await supabase
    64→    .from('reviews')
    65→    .select('rating')
    66→    .eq('worker_id', workerId)
    67→
    68→  if (reviewsError) {
    69→    throw new Error(`Failed to fetch worker reviews: ${reviewsError.message}`)
    70→  }
    71→
    72→  const avg_rating = reviews && reviews.length > 0
    73→    ? reviews.reduce((sum, r) => sum + r.rating, 0) / reviews.length
    74→    : 0
    75→
    76→  // Calculate final score using 40/30/30 formula
    77→  // Attendance is 40%, Punctuality is 30%, Ratings is 30%
    78→  // Ratings are 1-5, so we normalize: (rating / 5) * 0.3
    79→  const score =
    80→    (attendance_rate * 0.4) +
    81→    (punctuality_rate * 0.3) +
    82→    ((avg_rating / 5) * 0.3)
    83→
    84→  // Convert to 1-5 scale
    85→  const finalScore = Math.max(1.0, Math.min(5.0, score * 5))
    86→
    87→  return {
    88→    score: Math.round(finalScore * 10) / 10, // Round to 1 decimal
    89→    attendance_rate: Math.round(attendance_rate * 100) / 100,
    90→    punctuality_rate: Math.round(punctuality_rate * 100) / 100,
    91→    avg_rating: Math.round(avg_rating * 10) / 10,
    92→    completed_jobs_count: completedJobsCount,
    93→  }
    94→}
    95→
    96→/**
    97→ * Get reliability score history for a worker
    98→ */
    99→export async function getScoreHistory(
   100→  workerId: string,
   101→  limit: number = 20
   102→): Promise<ReliabilityScoreHistoryRow[]> {
   103→  const { data, error } = await supabase
   104→    .from('reliability_score_history')
   105→    .select('*')
   106→    .eq('worker_id', workerId)
   107→    .order('calculated_at', { ascending: false })
   108→    .limit(limit)
   109→
   110→  if (error) {
   111→    throw new Error(`Failed to fetch score history: ${error.message}`)
   112→  }
   113→
   114→  return data || []
   115→}
   116→
   117→/**
   118→ * Get current reliability score for a worker
   119→ */
   120→export async function getWorkerScore(workerId: string): Promise<WorkersRow | null> {
   121→  const { data, error } = await supabase
   122→    .from('workers')
   123→    .select('*')
   124→    .eq('id', workerId)
   125→    .single()
   126→
   127→  if (error) {
   128→    if (error.code === 'PGRST116') {
   129→      return null
   130→    }
   131→    throw new Error(`Failed to fetch worker score: ${error.message}`)
   132→  }
   133→
   134→  return data
   135→}
   136→
   137→/**
   138→ * Update reliability score for a worker
   139→ */
   140→export async function updateScore(
   141→  workerId: string,
   142→  score: number
   143→): Promise<WorkersRow> {
   144→  const { data, error } = await supabase
   145→    .from('workers')
   146→    .update({
   147→      reliability_score: score,
   148→      updated_at: new Date().toISOString(),
   149→    })
   150→    .eq('id', workerId)
   151→    .select()
   152→    .single()
   153→
   154→  if (error) {
   155→    throw new Error(`Failed to update worker score: ${error.message}`)
   156→  }
   157→
   158→  return data
   159→}
   160→
   161→/**
   162→ * Record a score history entry
   163→ */
   164→export async function recordScoreHistory(
   165→  workerId: string,
   166→  breakdown: ReliabilityScoreBreakdown
   167→): Promise<ReliabilityScoreHistoryRow> {
   168→  const historyData: Omit<ReliabilityScoreHistoryInsert, 'id' | 'created_at'> = {
   169→    worker_id: workerId,
   170→    score: breakdown.score,
   171→    attendance_rate: breakdown.attendance_rate,
   172→    punctuality_rate: breakdown.punctuality_rate,
   173→    avg_rating: breakdown.avg_rating,
   174→    completed_jobs_count: breakdown.completed_jobs_count,
   175→    calculated_at: new Date().toISOString(),
   176→  }
   177→
   178→  const { data, error } = await supabase
   179→    .from('reliability_score_history')
   180→    .insert(historyData)
   181→    .select()
   182→    .single()
   183→
   184→  if (error) {
   185→    throw new Error(`Failed to record score history: ${error.message}`)
   186→  }
   187→
   188→  return data
   189→}
   190→
